interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI have never claimed to be an expert on sport, but I do take notice when something is threatening the heritage that my constituents hold dear. The move to reduce the number of teams in the Rugby League is such a threat. Souths have a long, proud tradition in a community that supports them wholeheartedly. I, for one, do not want to see that tradition end. Souths are a working class team representing a working class area and they have been for almost a century. Their name, the Rabbitohs, comes from having two players in their early years who supported themselves by selling rabbits door to door, in the days when rabbit meat was pretty much the only meat that working class families could afford. So Souths boys are tough. There is a saying about Souths footballers that they would play footie with a house brick in the middle of the road if they had to.

speech.para: The area that I represent is an area which has changed a lot, but the working class parts of the electorate hold their traditions very dear. Their support for the Souths Rugby League team is one of those traditions. At the moment, there is a group called the Number 14 Group which includes a number of high profile people defending the Souths Rugby League team. They are organising a `reclaim the game' rally on 10 October at 11 a.m. However, more important are the tens of thousands of ordinary fans who support this team. More important are the kids involved in Souths Juniors, which has 160 teams competing, starting with under-6s. Whole families support this club.
Albert Clift is an example of such a person. He was interviewed in a recent Australian Story episode. Albert is 95 years old and he joined the club on 15 June 1922. Albert said:
What upsets me is the Rugby League was for the working class people and now they're trying to put these teams out of the competition for the silver tails.
Volunteer Eileen McLoughlin also appeared on Australian Story . She said:
I've been a Souths supporter since I was a little girl. I'm red and green. I'm one eyed. And I blame Mr Murdoch for all of this. I'll never buy his paper againâand I'll never take Foxtel.
These are just two examples of the type of supporter that is a diehard Souths supporter.

Because they are a team connected to their community, they take their responsibilities to the community seriously. They provide an inspiration for local kidsâand it is not always easy being a kid growing up in the inner city. There is not a lot of space to play. These young people face the same problems that young people throughout the country faceâunemployment, disillusion and so on. Souths play a very important role in visiting local schools. They also visit Long Bay jail and boys detention centres, where they provide inspiration to the inmates. Souths is a club with a history. It has a very strong local following. I think it is important to remember this and remember the true values of the sport rather than just focusing on the dollar.

In the minute that remains to me, I would also like to mention another issue that is very important in my electorate at the moment. McDonald's is proposing to build a restaurant in Moore Park. This proposal has been opposed not just by residents and the local council but by residents throughout Sydney. Moore Park is a historic park. It is the home of Federation. There is a proposal at the moment to refurbish the Grand Drive. In fact, $11 million has been granted from the Centenary of Federation Grants Scheme to refurbish the Grand Drive in preparation for the Centenary of Federation, and also in preparation for the Olympic Games, given that the proposed marathon and cycling routes will extend down the Grand Drive. What sort of message are we sending to the world if the images that are flashed out which should be the quintessential images of Sydney are instead the golden arches? I do not know if that is the sort of image that I want to have beamed around the world as quintessentially Australian.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to follow on after the words from the member for Sydney, because I rise tonight to express my concerns about media reports that the National Rugby League have confirmed that foundation Rugby League clubs South Sydney and North Sydney will not qualify for next year's 14-team premiership. If these reports are true, this will further alienate thousands of traditional rugby league supportersâthe men, women and children who have supported these two Rugby League clubs for many years. The real tragedy of this decisionâif it is to be confirmedâis that the general public, the people who support rugby league, have had no say in the decisions. The decisions have been taken by the faceless men of the NRL board, with no input from the rugby league supporting public.

speech.para: Most honourable members would be aware of the much publicised move by North Sydney to my electorate on the Central Coast of New South Wales, a decision that was supported and encouraged by the NRL, a decision that was difficult for the North Sydney club to take, but a decision that was warmly welcomed by the thousands of rugby league fans on the Central Coast. This decision was meant to be the rebirth of the North Sydney Bears. It was a decision that was influenced greatly by the building of the Grahame Park Multipurpose Stadium, a magnificent facility which will provide seating for up to 30,000 people, which is almost complete and will be in use before the end of this year and which I am proud to say was only made a reality by the provision of $12 million from the Howard government with a matching grant of $12 million provided by the New South Wales governmentâa huge amount of funding for a sporting facility in anybody's language.

There were many months of hard negotiations with the federal government and cabinet to ensure that the $12 million was allocated to Grahame Park. There is obviously a great deal of competition and need throughout Australia for the provision of sporting facilities, and Grahame Park was only one of a number of many outstanding applications. I know that one of the deciding factors in allocating the money to Grahame Park was that it would enable the North Sydney Bears to relocate to the Central Coast, to give the Central Coast its own identityâits own rugby league team in the Sydney competition. If the NRL are now going to walk away from this magnificent facility, it will be not only a tragedy for the Central Coast but a slap in the face for the faith of both the federal and New South Wales governments in Rugby League in New South Wales. One would think that it would be a very long time before either the federal government or any state government would consider contributing that sort of money again to a facility to be used for rugby league.

If the NRL does proceed with the scrapping of South Sydney and North Sydney, it will alienate hundreds of thousands of people. I know in my own area of the Central Coast there is a population of 300,000, a population that was looking forward to having a first grade rugby league team. Hopefully that will still happen in the form of the North Sydney Bears or, at the very least, an amalgamated team of North Sydney and Manly.

There is one last opportunity for rugby league supporters from both Souths and Norths to show their anger and their frustration at the possible decision that has been taken by the NRL. A march will start at 9.30 on Sunday, 10 October at Redfern Oval and there will be a rally taking place at the Sydney Town Hall at 11 a.m. Also on that Sunday I understand that the rally will proceed through the city of Sydney. This will be the last opportunity that South Sydney and North Sydney rugby league fans will have to show their support for their clubs and to show the NRL that what rugby league is all about is people, not corporate boards and not making huge profits out of rugby league.

If the NRL does not play first grade rugby league at Grahame Park, Grahame Park will still be a magnificent attribute to the city of Gosford. I know there are many other sports that are very keen to adopt Grahame Park. I understand that first grade soccer clubs are looking at Grahame Park. I know that baseball will be played at Grahame Park. Cultural events will also be held there. I understand that the Sydney Symphony Orchestra will be playing there. The very first event at Grahame Park will be the annual carols by candlelight festivities in December. Also, next year the Pacific island nations rugby union tournament will be played at Grahame Park. So whether or not the NRL games are played there, Grahame Park stadium will be a great success and will be a great asset to the city of Gosford. I am proud to have been able to play my part in making it a reality.

It would be sad if one of the few ovals which meets the NRL requirements and standards was rejected by the National Rugby League. Certainly the people of the Central Coast will not forgive the NRL if in fact this is the case.

talk.start.para: âIn this place we have debated the protection of workers' entitlements many times. Tonight I provide another example of just how necessary it is to legislate on this issue. There is a meat supplier in my electorate, Parrish Meat Supplies, at Yallah, which has been placed in receivership, with over 100 people losing their jobs. A report in the Illawarra Mercury on 18 August said:

speech.para: . . . it was hopeful the closure would not create another `Oakdale' and that employees would receive all of their entitlements.

Members will recall that the closure of Oakdale involved the loss of entitlements worth $6.3 million to 125 workers and that, after significant public pressure and an unnecessary coal strike, which the government provoked, legislation was rushed into this place to ensure the full payment of all entitlements. At Yallah today over 100 workers with families are owed their just entitlements. When companies are placed in receivership, workers are left to wonder just where their next payment will come from to pay the mortgage, pay for the food on the table, pay for the clothes, pay for the power, pay for the water and pay the local council rates.

This morning four of the workers owed money by Parrish Meat Supplies came into my electorate office. They came to brief me on the situation in regard to the negotiations to come up with enough of a bottom line for the company to meet its legal obligation. Here is a summary of the offer that is being put to these workers by the receiver. There are three options being put to the workers. The first option involves the payment of superannua tion under the liquidation scenario. This proposal would ensure the payment of $78,828 in superannuation obligations, and that is it. In the second offer, the annual leave and long service leave entitlements are put in, but not the superannuation obligation. Under this scenario, in liquidation the workers would receive just six cents in every dollar, which is the worst-case scenario. That would realise a miserly $21,172. Under the proposed deed arrangement, the annual leave and long service leave entitlements would be fully funded to 100 cents in every dollar, realising about $330,914. Option 3 includes a third-party ordinary unsecured claims estimate of $1 million, and an estimated redundancy claim of $265,163, an employee breach of contract claim of $123,649 and superannuation obligations of $78,828. This option pays out the full entitlements to the Yallah Parrish Meat Supplies workers, an amount of just over $1.4 million.

The Parrish Meat Supplies workers will be forced to accept option 2, ensuring the payout of their long service leave and annual leave, but they will lose out on their superannuation and any redundancy package they are entitled to receive. These situations are becoming more commonplace every day, and we sit here releasing discussion papers and involving ourselves in endless consultation. It is even more delinquent when the contributions of workers go missing. Why and how will be questions the Australian Taxation Office must now answer following its investigations.

As in the case of Oakdale, the Parrish Meat Supplies workers deserve the full payment of their legal entitlements, but the success of this campaign must also be provided by leadership from the union, in this case the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. I know its officials have been involved in negotiations with Parrish Meat Supplies, and they have my total support, but they and other unionsâas well as Iâneed to put incredible pressure on Parrish Meat Supplies to meet their obligations to their workers to the full cent.

The option that these workers are being asked to accept is not good enough. They deserve every last cent of their legal entitlements. We in this parliament must stop talking and start acting to protect workers' entitlements. It is bad enough that workers are losing their jobs because of insolvency; it is totally unacceptable that they lose money legally theirs too.

Today, following my meeting with these workers, I have requested that the Australian Taxation Office in Wollongong investigate the whereabouts of employee contributions to their superannuation. I am advised that Parrish Meat Supplies have not paid their legal superannuation obligations to their employees since at least January. But, worse than this, employees' own superannuation contributions appear to have gone absent without leave. Superannuation obligations are to help prepare workers for their retirement. It is something we encouraged when we were in office and it is a practice that continues to this day. It is unacceptable that any employer denies these obligations when there is a clear legal duty to provide such payments to their workers. I will continue to fight to make sure that the workers at Parrish Meat Supplies get their just entitlements. We must put a stop to this nonsense that is happening far too often, requiring us to come in here and make speeches such as this. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is not generally my practice to target individuals rather than the issue, or to look at the person rather than the policy. However, like the old feminist slogan `the personal is the political', there are occasions when the persona is so much a part of the political craft that one cannot be examined without the other. Tonight I refer to the honourable member for Dickson, the opposition spokesperson on transport and regional services. Yesterday she gave what turned out to be a truly remarkable media conference. Undeniably, the announced subjectâsafety issues in the long-distance trucking industryâwas, and is, of critical importance.

speech.para: Surveying the outcome today, Labor Party strategists must be reflecting that there is an awful irony about a media conference about road safety that turned out to be the public relations equivalent of a multiple heavy vehicle wreck. Instead of the media conference selling what should have been a positive message and a policy initiative, it turned out to be a self-justification as to why one could not spend more time in one's electorate, why one could not spend more time in regional and rural areas, and why one could not spend more time developing relevant policy.

Media coverage today ranged from `Kernot profile suffers from her heavy load' in the Sydney Morning Herald to `Ticking off for busy Kernot' in the Daily Telegraph and to `Kernot told to quit frontbench' in the Courier-Mail, her home town newspaper. All of this could be written off as simply media hype, except for comment which does bear further examination. In response to one question, the honourable member said:
I think we don't need to have another bush summitâ
apparently the Labor Party does not want to have another bush summitâ

we don't need to have regional forums going around the country listening, and listening, and listening as substitute for action, like the Coalition's doing. We're actually working on delivering things and the policy detail of delivering things, which I'm enjoying.

That bears some examination. On 26 February last, the honourable member issued a media statement calling on the government to bring forward its rural summit, which is scheduled for next month. That statement was issued after the release of the Bush Talks report by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the honourable member stated quite firmly that the rural summit should be brought forward. Yesterday she said that we did not need a summit. This raises the question of why the honourable member would want a summit to be moved forward and then want to cancel it at the end of September. I am sure that rural and regional people, whose representatives are preparing for it, would be interested to know what event, or events, in the past seven months has rendered the rural summit from an urgent and overdue priority to a complete waste of time, presumably, in the Labor Party's eyes.

Perhaps this utter disdain for the very idea of listening to rural and regional people is the real reason the honourable member has been so conspicuously inconspicuous in the areas which demand attention in her portfolio. Or maybe the Labor Party has suddenly realised that it has been the coalition that has been delivering. I would like to think that the Labor Party has realised that it is the government's programs and policies that are so effective, so on the mark and so popular in rural and regional areas that we do not need to listen any more. It is certainly a nice compliment but it is simply not so. We have a long way to go to make up for the appalling legacy of neglect that we inherited from Labor in 1996. But a willingness to listen puts us in sharp contrast to those on the other side of the House.

I, for one, will never let rural and regional people forget that the opposition spokesperson for transport and regional services believes that talking with them is a waste of time. We in the government believe that rural and regional Australians need to be heard; they need to be consulted. We look forward to the rural summit which is coming up in November as a great opportunity to further ensure, as the Deputy Prime Minister has said, that services are delivered in rural and regional areas, that there is a future for young people in rural and regional areas and, furthermore, that we are able to put new industries into rural and regional areas. I am disappointed that the opposition believes that it is not even worth listening to those who live outside our metropolitan cities. Such an attitude in opposition is merely alarming; in government it would be catastrophic.

talk.start.para: âI hope that the member for Dawson informed the member for Dickson that she was about to make those comments. This Sunday, 3 October, marks the first anniversary of a number of members entering federal parliament for the first time. Tonight I would like to take the opportunity to thank my family, friends, volunteers and the many wonderful volunteer groups in Canning who have made my first year so pleasurable. It has been a year in which I have met many wonderful volunteers and seen how they have worked to overcome the lack of resources by the federal government, particularly in the rural segments of my electorate.

speech.para: The first group that I would like to mention are the volunteers who work on the boards of senior age places in Canning. There are three main centres: Bedingfeld Park in Pinjarra, Amaroo in Gosnells and Dale Cottages in Armadale. Each of these boards works tirelessly to raise money to improve the conditions of their residents. But what we really need is more money for nursing home beds. It hurts every time I go to an aged care facility, particularly in Pinjarra, and hear of residents who are having to face the horrible decision to move away from the place where they have spent their entire lives. This needs addressing. It does not need listening; it just needs action.

In the city area, there are two groups who do superb work. The first is the Armadale home help group. They help senior citizens who want to spend longer in their own homes. They provide help in catering, gardening and taking people shopping if they need it. Again, they are volunteers and they are constantly under pressure for extra funding. Last week a number of us had the opportunity to see the older women's network perform at Parliament House. I was extremely proud of the performance put on by the Perth group and, in particular, the number of women from Gosnells in my electorate. These women sang wonderful songs that pointed out the failings of a GST, privatisation and lack of transport. Again, more action is needed. As I move around the electorate, I meet many councillors who work very hard and are dedicated to making our area a better place to live. They are to be commended for all the work they do.

Another area where we have a number of problems is with young people. There are two groups, Armadale Youth Resources and Emergency Accommodation in Armadale, whose staff work so hard and long to help young people get their lives back on track. This area is one where we need to be putting resources into helping young people find work. They need to be encouraged and they need to be provided with the training that is going to lead to employment.

Recently I attended the small business awards in Canning. This group encourages business people to further improve their efficiency. I was pleased to see a number of young people embarking on the adventure of business, something I did in my own youth. It is a wonderful way to learn. It is, of course, a difficult life and one that is not going to be made any easier with the burden of a GST and the proposed changes to the collection of taxation. This is going to put huge pressure on cash flow and demonstrates that the government does not really understand small business. We should be putting more work into this, because obviously small business is where employment is to be found.

One of the groups I have met is Kincare. They are families with children with disabilities. They provide support for each other. Again, they need additional funding. I am looking forward later in the year to being adopted by a family with three children, two of whom have disabilities, to help me better represent that group in my electorate.

I am going to have fond memories of the Yale Primary School, where they did a rousing rendition of She'll Be Coming Round the Mountain, complete with actions, for a long time to come.

I thank each one in my electorate for making my first year so good. I note with sorrow that two volunteers, Mr John Wright and Mr Dick Keegan, will not be available for future work. Sadly, they passed away recently. I extend my sympathies to their families. I look forward to working in Canning for a long time to come.

talk.start.para: âTonight I wish to comment briefly on the position with the reform of the petrol industry, the fuel industry, in Australia. I refer to it as the hydra-headed monster. It is made up of a number of very strong, powerful vested interests, all entitled to push their interests, as they have done. It is a body made up of major oil refineries, which also distribute fuel through wholesalers, generally owned or controlled by them, and retailers, generally controlled by major oil companies, some of them operated by small businesses. Those small businesses might in very rare cases own their own property and operate the business themselves under some contract with the major oil companies. In many cases also you will find that small businesses have actually leased their freehold to the oil companies and the oil companies then sublease the premises back to the owner of the freehold or an associated family entity. The small business carries on the business on their own property under an arrangement where the major oil company has become their landlord. Is it any wonder that the price of fuel in Australia, particularly in the bush, is subjected to some rather extraordinary mechanisms?

speech.para: The Howard government has had the courageâI might say it is the first federal government for 30 years to do soâto set out a plan to reform the fuel industry, the hydra-headed monster, and to try and provide some more equity, particularly for the motorists, the consumers, the forgotten people in this equation, living in regional Australia. The problem in Australia is that the fuel distribution system provides huge inequities to people living in rural Australia, and the gap in retail fuel prices between regional Australia and metropolitan Australia is extraordinarily large. In fact, it is not unusual to see the price of fuel sold by one of the major oil companies in regional Australia being 12c, 14c and 15c a litre higher than the price of fuel sold by that same major oil company in metropolitan Sydney or Melbourne. It is coming from the same refinery and is conveyed at the cost of 1c or 1Â½c maximum per litre in cartage, yet the price is so different, the gulf is so large.

The government has set about a plan to try and provide more justice and equity in the system and to provide more competition. Sadly, despite the government's efforts, which we will continue to pursue, the vested interests have failed to reach agreement amongst themselves as to how the fuel industry should be reformed. For literally two years now the vested interests have attempted to reach agreement on a code of conduct which would provide justice and equity between all the various players in the oil distribution system in Australia and provide a fairer deal to consumers. Those negotiations have broken down, and as a result of that Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, has announced that the government's proposals to proceed with the repeal of other legislation involved with the reform of the fuel industry cannot now proceed. In fact, the Senate will not pass it; the repeal cannot be passed.

This is very sad, because the Howard government has had the full support of the motoring organisations in Australia, the RACV and the NRMA. The reforms announced by the Howard government in 1996, which we still stand by, were fully supported by the motoring organisations as a breakthrough. The fact is that at this moment as I speak the reform that is so desperately needed in Australia is held up because the Senate has decided to support the vested interests, to endorse their lack of cooperation and to actually condone their lack of cooperation and to say to the government, `Despite the fact that we know the reforms are needed, we are not going to let you pass those reforms, knowing full well that the vested interests in the fuel industry have all agreed to disagree.' As a result of that, the Democrats and the Labor Party in the Senate have appeared to put the government in hold position. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: Has Australia undertaken negotiations to establish international agreements regarding the collection of indirect taxes from the exchange of electronic commerce: if so (a) what action and (b) what progress has been made.

talk.start.para: âThe Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: For the purposes of this response, indirect taxes includes both wholesale sales tax and GST.
The Australian Government actively promotes the discussion of electronic commerce issues in the international arena.

The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) provides a major forum for international debate and consensus on indirect taxation issues. The Australian Taxation Office (ATO), together with other Australian Government representatives, participates in the OECD's Committee on Fiscal Affairs and its subsidiary bodies.

At a meeting in Ottawa in October 1998 OECD Ministers, including Australia's, welcomed the OECD report entitled Electronic Commerce. A Discussion Paper on Taxation Issues. The report sets out a framework of taxation principles that should apply to electronic commerce and proposes a range of implementation options. ATO officers took a lead role in developing the framework.

The approach adopted by the OECD uses the taxation principles relating to conventional commerce as a guide and the Australian Government supports this approach. While not precluding new administrative or legislative measures to assist in the application of existing taxation principles to electronic commerce, the Australian Government has made it clear that it has no intention of imposing a discriminatory tax regime on electronic commerce.
Earlier this year, the OECD established a consumption taxes Technical Advisory Group (TAG) to further the debate on issues relating to consumption taxation of electronic commerce.
The TAG's membership is drawn from both government and business. Australia was recently accepted as a member of the TAG and ATO officers are currently representing Australia in this forum.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Lifeline Youth Services
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 851)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Will Goods and Services Tax (GST) be levied on funding provided to Lifeline Youth Services Queensland from the Commonwealth Department of Family and Community Services, the State Department of Youth and Community Care or other sources; if so, will Lifeline Youth Services be compensated; if so how.
(2) Will recycled clothing sold through markets and shops by Lifeline Youth Services Queensland be subject to a GST.

talk.start.para: âThe Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Generally, GST will apply to grants that are paid to registered bodies, where the grant is consideration for a taxable supply. Where the grant is a payment for goods and services by the grantee, GST will apply. Similarly in the case of financial assistance with performance criteria attached, or where an undertaking is given to perform particular services or functions in return for the grant, the Commissioner for Taxation is likely to rule that the grant is consideration for a taxable supply, and that GST is payable. It should be noted that the supply does not have to be made to the provider of the grant. For example, it could be a supply to a community sector.

GST will not be payable on government grants that are in the nature of donations or that are paid to bodies that are not registered for GST. For non-profit organisations, the threshold for GST registration is $100,000 per annum.

Where GST is payable on a grant. the funding organisation will be able to claim an input tax credit for the grant, and so the funding organisation can increase the level of funding to cover the GST payable by the grantee with no additional net outlay. If this occurs, the organisation receiving the grant will derive a cash flow benefit as it is entitled to retain the GST until 21 days after the end of the tax period in which the grant is received.

As part of the first phase of the GST rulings program, the Australian Taxation Office vs ill issue a comprehensive ruling on grants in November 1999. This ruling will explain the correct treatment of funding grants both by the agency which makes them and by the recipient.

(2) Supply of recycled clothing that is donated second-hand goods is GST-free when sold by a charitable institution a trustee of a charitable fund or a gift-deductible entity (a charity). Where a supply is GST-free then no GST is payable on the supplier is entitled to input tax credits on the creditable acquisitions that relate to that supply.
The supply of donated second-hand goods will remain GST-free no matter how many charities the goods have been supplied through since they were donated, provided they retain their original character.

Where the charity has reprocessed these goods so that they no longer have their original character, the supply is not GST-free and GST is payable, for example, where donated second-hand clothing is cut up and sold as cleaning rags. If the donated goods are merely cleaned or repaired prior to sale they will be GST-fee.
